questions.question: A patient was diagnosed with supraspinatus tendinitis. What degree of movement of the shoulder would present with pain in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 60-120 degrees Explanation: Supraspinatus tendinitis is a cause of Painful arc syndrome , also known as "subacromial impingement," is characterized by pain during a specific range of motion, usually between 60 and 120 degrees of shoulder abduction . Painful Arc Syndrome: Description Pain in the shoulder and upper arm during the mid-range (60-120 degrees) of gleno-humeral abduction. (Option B) Causes Minor tears of the supraspinatus tendon Supraspinatus tendinitis Calcification of supraspinatus tendon Subacromial bursitis Fracture of the greater tuberosity Pathogenesis The space between the upper end of the humerus and the acromion gets compromised, leading to the rotator cuff tendon being pinched between the greater tuberosity and the acromion during mid-abduction. Clinical Features Pain during mid-range of gleno-humeral abduction Tenderness at the supraspinatus tendon or subacromial space Restriction of shoulder movements Treatment Ultrasound therapy to the tender point Anti-inflammatory drugs Injection of hydrocortisone into the subacromial space Excision of the anterior part of the acromion Reference: Maheshwari Essential Orthopaedics 5th edition pages- 305,306.

questions.question: Which of the statements below is not true regarding the condition depicted in the image?

options.D: Seen on the dorsal and volar aspects of the wrist

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Less chances of recurrence Explanation: The image in the question is suggestive of Ganglion cyst . Ganglion cysts are more prone to recurrence . Ganglion cyst: Description Most common swelling of the wrist Arises from the synovial fluid of joint/tendon sheath Sites Most common: Dorsal > volar aspects of wrist (Option D) Clinical features Usually seen in young adults Well-defined, cystic, non-tender swelling Smooth, fluctuant and transillumination positive (Option B) Mucous containing cysts are associated with nail changes Rarely can cause compression of ulnar nerve Treatment Asymptomatic cases do not require treatment, spontaneously undergoes regression. USG-guided aspiration or Surgical excision is done in symptomatic cases and for cosmetic indications (Option C) Recurrence - common (Option A)
